review_title: Amazing project options to research and expand your horizons
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Long Beach, CA
pros: Research Experience: As a research assistant, you'll have the opportunity to gain hands-on experience in conducting research, which is valuable for your academic and professional growth. Networking: Working in a research environment allows you to connect with professors, fellow researchers, and professionals in your field, expanding your network and potential future collaborations. Mentorship: You'll likely have the guidance and mentorship of experienced faculty members who can provide valuable insights, advice, and support for your research endeavors. Skill Development: This role can help you develop essential skills such as data analysis, critical thinking, problem-solving, and project management, which are transferable to future academic or professional pursuits. Funding: Many research assistant positions offer financial support, including tuition waivers and stipends, which can alleviate the financial burden of being a full-time graduate student.
cons: Time Commitment: Balancing the demands of being a full-time graduate student and a research assistant can be challenging. It may require excellent time management skills to juggle coursework, research responsibilities, and personal commitments. Workload: Depending on the project and the expectations of your supervisor, the workload as a research assistant can be demanding, requiring long hours and potentially impacting work-life balance.

review_title: Great Benefits, Pay Could Be Better
job_title: Administrative Support Coordinator in Long Beach, CA
pros:
I worked within a academic department within the campus’ College of Liberal Arts, and the faculty and staff I worked with were nice and great to work with. Note: The atmosphere of one’s work environment can vary depending on the department. There were rumors that some departments have faculty that treat staff awfully. CSULB’s College of Business’ academic departments had that reputation while I was working there, but I have never witnessed staff maltreatment nor have met someone from those departments who could confirm the rumors.

I also enjoyed the work-life balance and working with students.
cons: The College of Liberal Arts offered me the lowest end on the salary range, which was around $16 per hour. It seemed like college hired an administrative services manager that is focused on saving the college money in part by not paying staff that much money. I was able to make more than $16 per hour by asking to be matched what I was making at my previous role. If you’re going to apply, be sure to know your net worth and be ready to negotiate salary. It seems like the only way to get a significant raise is by moving on to another position.

job_title: Associate Professor in Long Beach, CA
pros: The campus is beautiful. Students and faculty have free access to LBTransit buses. I highly recommended using public transportation because parking on campus is nearly impossible unless you come when it's dark in the morning and leave when it's dark at night. Take advantage of the plays and performances offered at the Carpenter Center and other theaters on campus. Visit the Japanese garden on campus. Walk the entire campus, not just the corner of the campus where your department is located.
cons: There is a great amount of turnover of faculty. The Retention, Tenure and Promotion process is a huge bureaucratic waste of time. Even if you achieve all the requirements for tenure and several enhancing criteria, your tenure depends on the composition of the committee making the decision, whether they like you or not, whether they are jealous of you or not, whether they are honest or not. Unfortunately, many tenured faculty who remain are mediocre at best.

job_title: CBA Graduate Programs Coordinator in Long Beach, CA
pros: Great benefits package that included health, dental, vision, supplemental life insurance, 401k/403b, and a pension plan. Employee discount on taking classes as well.
cons: Gossiping with a refusal to be innovative by more established employees (those who have been there for over 15 years). Director assigned to manage the team I was in, in my experience, had not had any managerial background (faculty are often assigned managerial duties by being made directors), which led to a chaotic work environment.   Differences of opinion regarding work assignments were often dismissed as disrespectful or insubordination by the assigned managerial faculty member.  This led to creating a toxic environment where employees felt intimidated.  Very high turnover without a desire from managers to fix it.  Best advice to a new hire in this college is too network to see what other opportunities may exist in other departments or use the skills that you may learn to advance your career elsewhere. In the meantime keep detailed documentation of your work to defend your work as needed.

job_title: Professor in Long Beach, CA
pros: Preparing young people for beneficial, productive careers and lives is important and you know that what you do matters. Compared to other professions, you have a lot of freedom to decide what you do and how you do it beyond your basic teaching responsibilities. Stimulating. Smart people around to talk with.
cons: University has become ever more bureaucratic. More and more reporting and regulations with less and less support. More restrictions. University and Departmental funding and support depends on throughput (graduation rates), not quality of education.  Without regard to need of different disciplines or careers, university imposes across the board cuts in course requirements and make it nearly impossible for students to change majors if they discover their life's calling after their fist year is completed - frustrating for training students to do important things that they were not exposed to before applying to college.  Oh, and Professors' salaries have dropped 5-15% compared to inflation in past decade - no financial reward for excellence or accomplishments...

job_title: Business Analyst in Long Beach, CA
pros: Lovely working environment campus and amenities , Helping Students and professors is rewarding not ripping clients money away of the time is nice.  Good work pace and friendly, benefits are great and insurance and retirement of course are awesome state provided.
cons: The pay is never the same as commercial , lack of drive to change things that are wrong or fix processes that do not work  is not there like in a commercial place where efficiency is everything.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Long Beach, CA
pros: My experience might be difference based on which professor you assist, but I had a great time as a GA.  In my particular case, there wasn't much work besides conducting review sessions and office hours, tutoring, emailing the students and professor, and grading.  The students, at least the ones that came talk to me, were kind and the professor was particular kind.  Technically I was supposed to have 10-hour work weeks, the actual work that had to be done normally took less time.
cons: The only con would be that a GA might have to grade essays or finals during finals week. Normally there are roughly 200 students in the class, but fortunately for me, I did not have much to do for the class I was an assistant for because my professor did a good chunk of the work.

job_title: in Long Beach, CA
pros: Great health care / retirement packages, but nothing else. Maybe free tuition, if you're getting a master's degree.
cons: Work here if you're lazy, like stable jobs, no drive for advancement, like a stable salary, and if you're old. This place is not for people in their 20s or their 30s, you have a lot to accomplish in life, don't waste your precious years here.

job_title: Advisor in Long Beach, CA
pros: State employee benefits, diverse student body, large campus, room for growth in developing professional skills, on campus professional development opportunities, recognized for being a competitive university that produces quality graduates
cons: There is a tendency to create positions that are incorrectly classified. There can be inequality among positions that shouldn't exist or they tack on job duties that involve higher levels of complexity. I've known staff members who have had to go through an HR desk audit to have their classification and pay increased. They also tend to open up positions as temp for one year and renew them for several years in a row as temp. No job security. Management was MIA often and not supportive when issues where brought up.

job_title: Research Assistant in Long Beach, CA
pros: Time was flexible as long as the required hours were put in. Weekly goals were set for the labs and the assistants would do their best to meet them. As an assistant, you have the option to choose how you want to implement your solutions to the problems presented. Various professionals would walk through and sometimes speak to the people present about the project, leading to opportunities to network.
cons: The project direction would change frequently, causing wasted time researching and sometimes work to be scrapped. Assistants weren't always accountable, leading to conflicts in design that had to be resolved.

job_title: Part-Time Lecturer in Long Beach, CA
pros: The location of the campus was very conveniently located in Southern California.  The student body was very large allowing courses to stay in curriculum when enrollment waivered.
cons: The red tape associated with the processes required to teach part time.  It required a significant amount of personal time to negotiate the various offices and approvals needed to get things done.  The lack of office administrative help available in some of the departments.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Long Beach, CA
pros: Basically a lifetime employment environment. Most managers and staff take a relaxed approach because there is no sense of external competition from other schools, no pressure from students (customers) to improve performance, etc.  There are a lot of long-term employees and therefore a lot of institutional memory and operational stability.
cons:
Management spends most of its time and efforts reacting to state-imposed initiatives. Not focused on campus excellence and student experience.
Union environment can be poisonous. Some truly awful staff with no accountability. This affects the morale of surrounding staff.

review_title: Kindgergarten teachers make more than me
job_title: Professor in Long Beach, CA
pros: none this place is HORRIBLE
cons: This is the WORST JOB ever. I honestly wouldn't have ever taken it if I had known how terrible it was. I am a full time, full professor, tenured. I have published at the level of someone at an R1 university. I have earned over 200K in external grant money. But I just got my last raise ever. I don't even make 6 figures. Anyone with a brain is penalized. THIS JOB IS FOR ZOMBIES or glorified elementary school teachers. But the CSU dislikes anyone who does well, and penalizes them instead of rewarding them. In fact, kindergarten teachers make more than me. My university expects us to give it all and get nothing in return. This is a GARBAGE JOB that makes me regret earning a Ph.d. in the first place. I'd be better off waiting tables.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Long Beach, CA
pros:
You are given independence on how you want to run your lab (with in reason), this also includes grading. 

Also get to request how many labs you want for the semester (up to 4), so if your expecting a heavy work load you can downsize how much extra work you'll need to do.
cons: Sometimes the labs you teach do not line up with what the students are learning in lecture, and the students usually end up blaming the instructor, even though you have no control over what lab is being taught each week. This was only a minor issue for me.

She would yell and me and us constantly and once even threatened to kill me in front of a customer.  I went to hr about her and her manager more times than I can count and nothing was ever done.  I was harassed and abused by this woman.  Even sexually harassed as she would tell me that she was in love with our boss and tell me about her sexual proclivities.  The final straw was when I caught her breaking into my PRIVATE Gmail account and reading my personal emails... when I took this information to management I was blamed for checking my email, even though it was allowed.  Instead of moving me to a less crazy manger or putting her on some sort of probation I was told that I (Only I, it was not a rule for all employees) was not allowed to use the internet for personal use (Something I later found out to be illegal) and shortly after I was fired.  
This was just my personal experience... this is on top of the senior staff members pulled out a pornographic magazine during an interview with a staff member looking to move into a new position. The. Pard members use the bookstore s their personal playground and take anything they want.  

This was my first "Real" job out of college and by far the worst experience I've ever had.  The pay was absolutely abysmal (The next job I moved to after this one right away paid me over 100% than I was making here, and that was still under the standard)
